												If you have ever played a game like sonic all-stars, Mario kart, f1 all-stars, rc revenge pro, diddy kong racing, crash racing series, modnation racers or little big planet kart you would love this game. I have played all of these titles and adored them, same story with table top racing. The game has superb graphics and quick loading times between races, and runs smooth as silk on my three-year-old slow laptop. While reviewing this game a new update came out so I asked Playrise Digital on their website question form the new features and the team responded hours later. There are 6 championships or 'Cups' to complete and several special races which may require certain wheel types  and cars to participate. The vehicles are divided into three tiers/categories; Amateur (Cult Classics), Pro (Street Racers), Expert (Super Cars) which have four different vehicles to choose from in each category. From the base game there is five different style of race tracks (tables) but four variations of the course. Each car can be upgraded in top speed, acceleration, handling, armour as well as choose from four styles of paint and seven different styles of wheels. Each wheel is unique and gives a different attribute to the car; Standard, Drift (For Drifting), Bling (For Bonus Coins/Money), Sheild (Force field around the car), Centurion (Spike Wheels), Boing (Allow your car to jump/bounce and reach coins on some tables) and Peace Bomb (Disarm weapons). One thing to note is when you buy the wheels which are fairly expensive, you can use them on everyone car without having to rebuy. Opponents do not have weapons wheels until the Expert difficulty cups however, opponents may have weapon wheels in special events.There are seven different types of events; elimination (last car standing), time trial (quickest time over a set amount of laps), hot lap (quickest lap), Combat race (Race with power ups), pure race (Race without power ups), drift (race with drift wheels for drifting) and pursuit (catch up to a slower car and tag). In combat race there are several power ups; Acid, Rocket, Tracking Rocket, electric pulse, boost, bomb and ice beam, which once you pick up two power ups you get a special upgraded power up upon reaching Pro difficulty. The cars in the game generally handle with ease, however the cult classics are a challenge to turn. The opponents are extremely easy to beat in the first two difficulties but the game gets more challenging later in the game, especially the pursuits. The game also has online only multiplayer which I find impossible to find a server in Australia, the game allows the creation of one though. While typing this line I found one server and played, there was a slight jagged feel when controlling my car although this may be an internet issue for the other player. However, at this current update there is no local co-op multiplayer aka split-screen, which is a real disappointment. If you decide to purchase the 'Supercharger' DLC you get three additional championships one each vehicle tier, four additional cars, one extra track 'Can Ya Dig It?' and 16 extra special events. Included is a great drift car which will be useful if you struggle with the drift events like myself. Please do note if you want to play with some people online you need this dlc. The game features upbeat, electronic dance music which adds a nice feel to the game with a nice variety of 17 tracks by WES SMITH which you can listen to on soundcloud: https://soundcloud.com/itswessmithyo . Conclusion:Table Top Racing: World Tour World Tour by Playrise Digital is a great indie title to play with friends or alone with a nice selection of vehicles, customizations and maps. The game does lack variety of tables, however I do not mind this as the game is highly addictive, and will provide at least 10 hours of fun. It is now your turn to decide whether a $20 USD price tag is a good price for the game.*Please do note that I have received this game for the purpose of reviewing it*

												Table Top Racing: World Tour (TTR from now on) is a racing game that takes place on…..well, what do you think? Tables of course! The BreakdownKart racers have been around for eons, but what about…..car racers? Y’know, kart racers with real-looking cars? I suppose that’s what I’d describe TTR as. It feels like a kart racer yet the vehicles have the appearance of realistic cars, vans, or trucks. Normally I’d talk about gameplay first, but hey, why not graphics this time? Let’s switch things up! So, the game has a sort of realistic look to it, like I mentioned earlier. The tracks all consist of a table (or what generally looks like somewhere in a house) with various household objects (food, bottles, etc.) spread around the track/table. As you drive your little cars around you can then knock a lot of the stuff on the track over, which is pretty fun. The cars themselves are just a mix of realistic-looking race cars and knockoffs of cars from pop culture (the Breaking Bad RV, a “fauxrari”, etc.). Everything in the game looks pretty crisp and polished overall, so graphically I definitely have no complaints. Now onto the gameplay. Here’s where things are both good and bad. See, the game basically consists of you driving your little car around a track over and over until you win. That’s….basically it, however there’s a small variety of modes to mix things up. From the main menu there’s “Championships”, “Special Events”, and “Multiplayer”. Championships is the meat of the game, and it’ll last you about 5-8 hours or so depending on how skilled you are at racing games. Within Championships you’ll find 6 different cups with a variety of events to choose from. These events are one of a few different game modes (Combat races where you can use powerups, pure/no weapons races, a “pursuit” mode, elimination, time trials, drifting, and a “get x lap time” mode), which helps to keep the gameplay from getting too stale. On top of that, there’s collectable coins scattered around each track in some interesting hidden locations so even if you’re terrible at the game it incentivizes you to collect them and use the money they give you to upgrade your car (or buy a new one) and get better.The Special Events mode is basically a variety of events, like in Championships mode, yet there’s some very minor twists. It’s just extra content I suppose. I never got to try out the multiplayer unfortunately (no one was playing online), so I can’t comment on that mode.Generally I enjoyed my time with TTR, but what did I dislike? Well, to start, the tracks. There’s…..5 of them. That’s slightly remedied by the slight variation given to them during certain events (I believe the game refers to each track’s variations as “track A”, “track B”, etc.), but after playing what is basically the same track over and over it gets a bit old. I’d have really liked to have seen more tracks, not just the same 5 ones over and over with tiny changes here and there.Secondly, the game’s handling feels weird, at least to me. Maybe this is just a personal thing but it felt like on every turn my car would either hit a wall (at least initially) or just barely make the turn, while the AI seemed to make turns at full speed just fine. Now granted, with handling upgrades on the best cars in the game it’s not too bad, but when I had first started playing it was definitely frustrating watching myself hit walls on almost every turn. I think the speed of the cars is pretty fitting but their handling could definitely use some work, Beyond that, there’s not a whole lot to talk about with TTR. It’s fun I suppose, and pretty well-made overall. Err…...oh wait, that’s right - the music. It’s uh…..well, I think some people will enjoy it. Personally I thought it was mostly generic hip hop/electronic/dance stuff, so sometimes I just felt like muting the game and turning on my own music while I raced. However, I feel as if it’s not terrible, but simply “tolerable”, if that makes any sense. Also there’s a song that says “be drunk” repeatedly. I….I don’t even know.ProsFun, energetic kart racer gameplay across dozens of fairly varied events - racing little toy cars on tabletops is quite exciting and silly compared to real racesDecent vehicle customization is included (wheels, car types, stats, and paint jobs can all be changed)The graphics are fairly good overall - no complaints thereThe music is fairly fitting - it’s upbeat and energetic but also a bit laid backThere’s Steam achievements, cloud support for saves, and controller supportConsThere’s only 5 tracks (even if the game advertises 20 - there’s 4 slight variations to each of the 5 base tracks), so more would definitely be betterCar handling feels bizarre - AI cars turn fine, but for some reason (especially with early cars or ones that aren’t upgraded) you can only take turns super wide by default, which causes a lot of wall crashes to happenSome people may not like the music (personally I didn’t care much for it)Table Top Racing is a pretty solid fast-paced racing game with powerups. There’s a lot to like here, from the lovely visuals to the decent amount of variety in both customization options and game modes. Despite my problems with it, primarily the small number of tracks and some weird  turning problems (which are fixed with vehicle upgrades), I honestly really enjoyed playing this game. Bravo, developers - you’ve made a pretty great little racer! Final Verdict: 8/10

												Table Top Racing: World Tour is a mini car racing/combat racing game. This review is coming from someone who is not a fan of the racing genre and I tend to avoid racing games. This game however is an exception to that as it is extremely fun and very entertaining. It’ll remind you of Mario Kart, F1 race stars, those old Hotwheels games etc. The game is very polished and I was surprised how good the production quality is for an Indie game. Graphics:The graphics are very good, you can change settings to low, medium, high and ultra, depending on your system specs you can adjust accordingly. As it’s a table top racing game, the maps are filled with all sorts of stuff such as huge pool balls, spray cans even sushi plates and such, the cars are those cute small cars with huge wheels and they look adorable. Sound:The game features upbeat, fast paced, techno-ish soundtracks which are very suitable for racing games as it’ll keep you pumped up. There’s plenty of tracks so you won’t get tired of listening to the same tracks over and over again. Gameplay:The gameplay consists of, well, world tours of racing. You have 3 categories of races, there’s the “Amateur” level which will have the cult classic cars such as the Volkswagen beetle lookalike, Ford Mustang, Mini Cooper etc. There’s even a camper van called “Braking bad” which I thought was a hilarious reference to, you know, Breaking bad. Then there’s the “Pro” level which has street racer cars such as Nissan 350z, Skyline even a Range Rover type of car etc. The last but not the least is the “Expert” level which has super cars like Ferrari or “Fauxrari”, McLaren or “McHandful” as the game tells it. All the cars’ names will be different than their original counter-part I guess due to licenses and other such legal matters.The cars’ physics and feel is very arcade-y as it should be for a table top racing game. The cars handle fine and have plenty of upgrades/paintjobs/bling-bling rims etc. There’s quite a few customizable items to unlock. The cars also have special wheels/rims which affect your car e.g. there’s the Spartan blade rims which will damage the other racers’ cars when brushing against them. Every time you win or lose a race you will get coins and the 3-star system which will give you stars depending on how well you did on that race/event. You can use these coins to buy new cars or upgrade your already bought cars. One car in all 3 levels are unlocked for you from the start, rest you will have to buy with coins. There’s a lot of stuff which can be bought with coins, paintjobs, wheels, performance upgrades etc.You have a bunch of different types of racing modes available such as racing with power pickups, time trials and best lap time modes. The maps are small enough and most events have short races which are usually 1-2 minutes long with 3-5 laps. There’s plenty of themes like of the maps like a workshop theme which will have all those car parts lying around, sports theme such as pool stuff, kitchen theme with vegetables, sushi etc.You can also get power-ups in races such as speed boost (sort of like nitro), rocket, bombs etc. The usual type of power ups available in any combat racing game. The AI is pretty good and will try to screw you over every chance it gets. There are 3 types of racing levels, or leagues. Each has 3 tournaments which you can beat and get the trophies. The multiplayer mode is pretty dead, as of writing this review I could not find anyone playing online but then again it’s morning where I am right now so I guess people will be on at night time (as is usual for me with multiplayer games). 												Table Top Racing is a very aptly named game, because you race around on various sorts of tabletop surfaces. I'm not sure about the World Tour part, though I did see an American Flag in one level and a Union Jack in another, which I guess are flags corresponding to different parts of the world. Four out of five words is pretty good for a title.Now I couldn't really make my mind up on whether I liked this game or not. I spent an extra five or so hours more than I feel this game deserved trying to decide. The graphics seem to lend to an illusion of this game being much better than it really is, at least for me as someone who enjoys racing games quite a bit. The flaws to the game and total lack of documentation on certain game features lend to my depreciating opinion on the game.I know a lot of people will compare this to similar games on Steam like Toybox Turbos or Super Toy Cars and I'd definitely put this on a similar quality level. The graphics are much better but the gameplay lets it down a fair bit.The handling model is incredibly simple and doesn't interact at all with the physics. If your car is acting under physics, whether you hit an object, got rammed or just landed after a jump, you have no control over your car until that stops. You have very mild 'air control' which is the same level of control you have while on the ground. This means the most powerful weapon in the game is ramming someone from the inside on a corner and makes the handling feel very inconsistent. Not to mention, the physics system itself isn't perfect by any means after landing from certain jumps or even little bumps in the track I've had my car rocket in total random directions. The very simple handling model and poor physics implementation means the meat of the game, the actual driving, is very hit and miss. I could forgive it if the game didn't force jumps on every track but every long race I was just constantly in fear of the next jump destroying my chances of coming 1st.The AI doesn't offer much challenge either, none of them take any shortcuts, they all follow one racing line and drive at set speeds and only ever fire their weapons at you. This means the best events become the Time Trials, Hot Laps and Drift Events since all of the Combat Race style Events are braindead easy provided the physics don't screw you over.This in itself wouldn't be a bad thing either, but there's no Single Race mode, you can't pick any of the tracks you've raced on, pick a mode and some settings and have some fun. You have to race on their preset events, whether they're in the Championships or Special Events. There might be a track you really want to drift on with your favorite car, but unfortunately you're not able to.They're working on local multi-player, so perhaps this could come in a future update, but as of writing this review, this feature's not in the game.There's also a lot of undocumented features. Lots of weapons in the game counter a weapon and are countered by another. Like bombs attracting Heatseeking Missiles or the Electricity blowing up the Bombs. Some of the pink glowing things on the side of the track are Shortcuts which can be opened by hitting them with a Level 2 powerup, the things that aren't shortcuts usually toss some debris on the track. There's a boost start you can use at the start of the race somehow which was recently added in an update. There's also a lot of little things on the tracks you wouldn't be able to find out without making a serious effort to. Like the orange GO! Sushi signs on the Sushi shop track actually being little doors you can drive through. Or the Circular Saw on the Workbench track actually hiding a shortcut you can take. I understand some of these things are meant to be 'secrets' but if you have some shortcuts highlighted and others not it doesn't really make sense. It's just confusingly inconsistent for no real reason. The level 2 weapons are also locked at the beginning of the game for some reason so you don't even really know they exist, which means things like shortcuts are unavailable to you as well.Now the Drift Mode for the game, even though I've been decidedly negative about it this whole review, I found to be quite enjoyable. The DLC also adds an AE86 that's 'Legendary' for drifting, so I spent a good amount of time sliding around in the few available drift events I could use that car in. I'd personally say it's the best part of the game even if it's limited. There's also another great undocumented 'feature' in that a lower handling rating makes a car drift better. Especially useful on cars with lower drift ratings and high handling ratings like the Supercars.Overall, I wouldn't recommend this game just because I hate the way the physics are handled. For a casual racing game player, once you start racing on the more difficult tracks I could see the difficulty spiking way up, especially with all the hidden things that aren't really common sense. For someone more experienced, the game won't challenge anything except your patience with the poor physics. A little more effort and it could have been a brilliant game.

Table Top Racing blurs the line between the Arcade Racing and Kart Racing genres, by adding the ability to shoot projectiles and collect power ups to the demolition derby feel of the more realistic cars of Nascar. They end up with a racing game that feels like a Matchbox car derby, very nostalgic, with super fantasy table top track setups ranging from a sushi diner counter, to an eighties memorabilia lined attic shelf, to the floor of a garage. I received a copy free for review purposes, but that in no way influenced the fact that I love this game! I grabbed the DLC myself. ∙،°. ˘Ô≈ôﺣ » » » The Cars: These vehicles handle superbly. I prefer to use my Steam Controller, but the controls are simple enough to work with any device. The wide variety of vehicle models includes standard super cars, hippy campers, and pickup trucks. If you’ve played the Disney Infinity 1.0 Cars Playset, you’ve seen how the fantasy addition of not-so-standard race cars can amp up the laughs, adding a much needed jolt to the fun factor in derby type racing. But, these cars each have their own set of strengths and weaknesses added to the cosmetic beauty of the car to create an addictive collectors  aspect to the game much like that of collecting Matchbox cars for children. Personally, I can’t wait to earn the Fauxrari. But, the availability of other upgrades may forestall that acquisition. The Upgrades:  Comical sounding names for tires like: bling, boing, and shield let you know right up front what these tires can do for your ride. The boing tires are one of the more expensive to earn with the in-game currency, but give you the ability to alter typical game physics in a more satisfying way, and allow you to reach more hidden coins and shortcuts. The Bling tires, aside from the ascetic benefit, cause you to earn more money from races, though they don’t really help you win. There are quite a few tire options. Adding more would definitely be better, of course.  But, there are also cool paint jobs you can earn, and of course the leveling up of abilities, like acceleration, max speed, and handling. The TracksThe race tracks are atypically short for most of the kart racers I’m familiar with, more in line with standard stadium race tracks length-wise. There is no stadium feel here, however. It feels like being a kid lying on the floor of a garage, racing your Matchbox cars between old car parts and cans of transmission fluid. Or, like racing your hot wheels around the diner counter past the napkin dispenser. So, there is quite a bit of nostalgic pleasure derived from the game no matter who you are. But, the myriad of objects to drift into, collide with, and knock off the track, along with the ability to careen over the edge of the table adds the pleasure of riding the bumper cars.  Multiplayer: If you enjoy the thrill of mastering all the championship trophies, and exploring the special events, then you will simply love the gameplay of multiplayer, which is where the real meat & potatoes of the game is found. You could spend many hours in single-player racing against the AI, but eventually you will want more than the scaling of typical AI races. Multiplayer becomes more of a competition, and a friendship forming opportunity. Though there is no co-op yet, MP certainly lends itself to teaming up against your opponents. The game could certainly benefit from that option. Pros:*Excellent, beautiful graphics!*Supercharged Cars –fantastic rides!* Challenging tracks and championship options* The Weapon-Wheels are a great addition to the genre/ Spike wheels! Need I say more?*PVP MP combat racing with up to 8 players *NO glitching, bugs, or loading errors of any kind Cons:*Scaling – I’m not too big of a fan of this common race strat, as it seems more like an exploit (I’d rather be lapped a few times when I really suck- more realism)*No co-op team racing *More is better… more content would be great My overall verdict is a 10 out of 10 for this incredibly fun arcade racer. If you love it as much as I do, you’ll definitely want to grab the DLC, for the… well you know… more of everything I mentioned, since more is better. And, the game & dlc are both well worth the pricing. Currently the game is being bundled with the DLC on pc so you basically get the DLC free.  I highly recommend these supercharged racers for everyone, and their brother!

No launcher to change monitor selection; doesn’t save the last value so it will return to Monitor 1 when launched. Fullscreen toggle on F1, disabling the standard Alt-Enter. There are a few unskippable intro logos, and can't be disabled in the configs.Toggles for AA/DOF/V-sync, and a few levels of Ambient Occlusion (which seem unoptomized and impact performance heavily) can be changed mid-race, while volume sliders (SFX and Music) only show up in the primary options menu. Excluding the AO, it supports unlimited framerates and should be easy to run, though at a solid 120FPS, I noticed off-and-on stuttering more or less depending on the track. Seems like a v-sync or borderless window related confluct; it doesn’t seem to maintain the fluidity that such a high framerate should offer.Renders wider than 16:9 properly, but the HUD contorts and loses a few elements, and the menus UI become essentially unusable. No FOV adjustment (default didn’t bother me) but there are 4 camera distances.Two preset button configs for controllers (trigger vs face button brake/throttle), with almost full rebinding (excl. menu navigation inputs) for the keyboard. Controller bindings are intuitive and the menus responsive, with a few small issues. Vertical menus don’t loop around; you see this when exiting the game as it’s at the bottom of the list, and they left the PS4’s “Trophies” button in which now does nothing.The event menus need work; championships use a larger grid with 2 layers vs horizontal event cards for Special Events. Having all of the event icons and star ratings, and the event cards are good, so a side-by-side approach would have worked better for both, unifying all of it. One pro; it stores your skin/wheel/upgrade selections per-car, saving some time.Gameplay6 modes to play [ Races w/ & w/o weapons (7 AI), Hot Lap (the best single lap within a time limit), Time Trial (time to complete x number of laps), Elimination (each lap removes car in last), Pursuit (catch up and bash into a car that starts far ahead of you), and Drift (points increase the longer you keep a combo, holding a combo lets you continue past the timer) ] on 20 track routes through 5 locations. Tracks feature a number of shortcuts locked behind objects and elevation, accessed via the 8 familiar weapon pickups (forward only, more effective after picking up a second) and 6 unlockable wheels with offensive/defensive/movement capabilities.I have a knack for racing games so this may be skewed; I found the majority of the game to be far too easy. Handling is F1 with heavy traction control. Without the dedicated drift wheels, there’s almost no slide and there’s no handbrake, nor does there seem to be a way to lose traction and force an overseer with the throttle. Most sliding happens after jumps just before a turn, as you’re allowed mid-air rotation. The opposite of drift-focused arcade racers, you’d expect following a proper racing line to be key. It doesn’t seem to carry enough momentum for that to be enough of a factor, especially for the low and medium tier vehicles; I didn’t find them to be all that engaging to drive. The game only finds itself with the highest tier, and I’d quite like another faster beyond that.Shortcuts make certain challenges dramatically easier, and range from elevated sections accessed by jumping (on cooldown) with the Boing wheels, large gaps that can be cleared the same way, and hidden jumps/paths behind objects opened up by the second stage of all weapons except boost (breakable objects have a pink sheen). AI ignores all of it, so they aren’t often necessary.The most fun I’ve had has been in the Drift mode. With the right car (some better than others; their drifting potential is listed on car selection screen) it isn’t too difficult, and is very satisfying as you slide through the turns with a lot of control, but have to plan ahead in a way that you don’t for standard races. You get a similar feel by using drift wheels for other races, but that’s usually a hindrance as you don’t have much control over the grip to prevent sliding on subtle turns, and there’s no acceleration advantage coming out of turns (like other arcade titles with drifting) that would help balance it out.Progression & Pay Model[Character Limit - See Full Review]PresentationThey adorable car models are honestly the most detailed and polished I’ve seen from this genre, and their designs are so appealing to me that I’d genuinely be interested in buying physical models. The surrounding aesthetic has a few rough spots, but uses a nice variety of shaders and materials. The colorful lighting is basic but sound, but the cars lack distinct cast shadows in some of the indoor locations, and the outdoor Junkyard and Egypt locations lack ambient lighting that would mimic the indirect sunlight, making shaded areas darker than they should be.The UI and HUD feature an odd selection of fonts/styles, though it’s functional outside of a lack of feedback concerning lap counts and position. Most sliding happens after jumps just before a turn, as you’re allowed mid-air rotation. The opposite of drift-focused arcade racers, you’d expect following a proper racing line to be key. IntroductionTable Top Racing: World Tour is a mini-car/kart racing game in a similar vein to Mario Kart, that is to say where you have a small sized vehicle collecting power-ups to use against your enemies as you race around the small track. The visuals are great, but in my opinion, the sound track leaves a lot to be desired.Gameplay ImpressionsIn Table Top Racing: World Tour you find yourself driving miniaturized versions of what could very well be real world cars. These mini-vehicles fit right in with the littered table top racing theme. Much of the debris lying around the track can be knocked out of the way. The racers can strike them as they drive around the course at the cost of only a minor loss of momentum. While there are really not that many varieties of tracks available, there are plenty of different race types to make up for it. Sometimes a lack of variety can be a bad thing. It could get boring with the same old, same old, but when it comes to racing games, knowing the track is the best way to give yourself an edge. Having fewer tracks to memorize allows you to spend less time crashing during unexpected sharp turns and more time winning races.The game is divided into different cups, two cups per tier, and three tiers total. As you progress through the cups, more race modes will become available. I won’t go into an exhaustive list of every race type, but I will name a few of the more interesting ones. Battle Cars is the default mode. In it, it plays like Mario Kart. You race around the track trying to come in first place while using weapon pickups to slow down your opponents. Your enemies can also use those weapons, so you will have to be ever vigilant to maintain or improve your position in the race. There is also a more vanilla race mode that is just purely about racing skill rather than using cheap tricks to give yourself an edge. Drift mode is a fun mode; in it you try to slide around corners as fast as you can without hitting the walls, maintaining the drift until just before you lose control you straighten out and drive sensibly again. In Drift, you are not against other opponents; you simply are trying to beat one of the top three track scores in order to earn your bronze, silver or gold stars for the mission. There are the time trials which are similar, race against the clock to score the best lap record or best course completion time. There is also a cat and mouse style mode. You are the cat so to speak, and your goal is to catch up to the much faster mouse and pounce on it, or in car speak, ram into it. You do this through clever and creative means such as using your boost at opportune times and taking short cuts. At the end of each cup is a multi-race event that requires you to do well in each of the races in order to move on to the next cup. There are other modes and multiplayer, but you get the idea, there is plenty to do.Each tier of racing comes with four car options. When you first start the game you can only afford to buy one of the first two available for the tier. Once you earn more by participating in races, you can either opt to buy a different car or upgrade the one you have. Each car will have different balances between their speed, acceleration, handling and armor. You will want to figure out which stats are more important to you when purchasing the car. Just because that one car has more slots for speed, it might not accelerate all that well so you might not actually get up to full speed all that often. The customizations don’t end here though. The wheels on the cars can be customized as well. The wheel customizations have a variety of effects and unlike the other car tuning upgrades, you unlock them once and you can use them on all cars you own. For example, you can equip wheels that cause you to earn more money from using weapons on enemies. You can also use wheels that give you a shield against some weapons, or even turn your wheels into weapons. There are others, but basically this adds a whole extra layer of strategy and fun to the game. Lastly you can paint your vehicles. I don’t believe painting them really has any kind of effect other than a cosmetic one. Odds are you better off sticking with stock until you have bought everything else you need. Visually, as mentioned, this game looks great. It isn’t cartoony like Mario Kart, it actually looks somewhat realistic. The mini-cars really suit the “you are racing on the top of a table” style of the game. The random household objects and foods lying around as you drive through the various environments enhance the table top feeling even more. Overall, the visuals are very well done for the game. There were not even any graphical glitches that occurred for me, not even minor ones. The sound on the other hand, that is something to talk about. The sound effects are your standard racing ones. Nothing really stands out there, but you don’t exactly want random nonsense sounds when racing around, you want to hear those standard sounds. The sound effects therefore are perfectly fine. The sound track on the other hand… well I read in other reviews people really like the sound track for this game. That’s great; I can see people liking it, but it was far from my style of music. Not wanting to be harsh, I would still have to say, the sound track is the kind of music that I typically wouldn’t actually class as music. It’s pretty much all remixed breakbeat (a kind of a funk/hip hop/electro/dubstep/techno blend). It’s the kind of music typically played at raves and other parties that I try to avoid being invited to. I tried my best to endure it and actually caught myself almost sort of liking one of the music tracks, but I realized that was just the Cognitive Dissonance kicking in. Luckily, you can turn off the music without losing the sound effects and play your own music if you are so inclined. Overall, this is an excellent power-up racing game with tons of customization options and plenty of race varieties. The only real detractor is that I dislike its soundtrack immensely. Some reviews agree with me, others say it gets you into the racing spirit and mood. So hit up your favourite music streaming site, look up remixed Breakbeat and give it a listen. If your ears are not bleeding too heavily after that, go out and purchase this game!Pros:Great visuals, using a more realistic setting with mini-cars was a better design choice than attempting to pull of the cartoony visuals of Mario Kart or Sonic All-Stars RacingPlenty of customization optionsMultiple race event types per cup help prevent the game from getting repetitiveHidden coins make even losing a race fun. Rather than “rage quitting” when you are in last place, take the time to explore the track for all the hidden coins. The extra money will help you upgrade or replace your carControls are fluid and responsiveCons:Sound Track “music” that is less enjoyable than listening to nails on a chalkboard that is backed by bagpipes and cats in heat. Not many varieties for tracks, the same tracks get recycled over and over again with some obstacles moved around or replaced

I wish that there's more gamified/cartoonified elements of real-world racing in the game here. Some examples I could think of are:- quick tire wear (loss of grip after 5 or so laps, maybe have a 20-lap endurance race?)- quick fuel consumption (in the same line of thought with tire-wear, varies with each car)- component damage (too much crashing into others, damage to overall performance)- track rules (not sure how this can be implemented, but a quirky full-course yellow and a stop-n-go penalty would be amusing)- pit stops (complements the tire wear and fuel consumption)Mind you, I'm mostly a sim racer when it comes to a car race. This game is  alright  by every sense of the word. Table Top Racing: World Tour is...well...a racing game. The biggest appeal they push is small cars on table surfaces like work desks at an auto-shop or a sushi bar. The lack of content and overall non-uniqueness bring this games quality down, begging for a price change. I will reccomend it however with the case of waiting for a sale. Now let's get started!!!!For starters, let's get that TL;DR out of the way!+Good Graphics+Pick-Up and Tire powerups+Several Game Modes+Online Multiplayer+Tracks don't look alike+For me, Good performance+Ugrade Vehicles with in game money you win-Unlike Sonic, Mario, Flatout, Gas Guzzlers there is no named racers. So making a rivalry [like I hated Jason from Flatout] or making your own makeshift narrative doesn't happen. This also brings no character to the competition-Only 3 classes of cars with 4 in each.-Only 2 cups in each class-Each gamemode feels old...like classic is good of course but, there is no new feel to it. Rather just go play another racer that has done it better or made it feel new with some extra mechanic.-Powerups are your typical powerups...ice blast, shockwave, rocket, homing rocket, all generic powerups.-Can not shoot some powerups behind or foward [so if the rocket shoots foward, you cant shoot back]-Day 1 DLC [this doesn't bother me....but it bothers most]So 7 pros and 7 cons....my feelings for this game are very mixed at the moment. Stick around for the full review!!! I am going to put a tad bit more time into it just to make sure my claims are valid, do a video and I will come back later to write out the long winded review. See ya soon!-Update-Okay so to give you a bit of an overview of the content I haven't yet brought up:There is a championship mode, special events mode, multiplayer. There is no quick race or custom race in singleplayer.There is a few secrets such as short cuts and coins...but not many.There is only two track hazards: falling off the table top and objects like dice, cups, spray paint cans you know...it depends on the setting. I like this, but they don't really have much of an effect. I've slammed into many of them, they just go flying and I keep truckin'There isn't much in the way of dynamic gameplay. No random track events, no dangerous tracks, nothing like that. Powerups This is my biggest beaf with this game. The power ups are not satisfying at all. Take mario, sonic or gas guzzlers extreme. When you shoot someone with a power up, you see them explode or go ape crap. But here, a rocket hits a car..little bit of black smoke...then nothing. The electric shock, acid, mines all of that look so weak in nature.The recovery time is also atrocious. You recover so quickly that the power up attacks affect maybe .5 seconds of progression. The power ups I remember are as follows, keep in mind I don't know the official names:Homing RocketRocketFreeze shot [you shoot someone and they turn into an ice cube]acid trailelectric shockboostminesand there is one more I can't remember.
